entry.title: Re: Particular Z* report hangs CI when runs there but not...
entry.content:
This behavior is expected in some landscapes and is usually due to different memory distribution and workload characteristics on CI vs. application servers.

On the CI, dialog processes also handle enqueue, update, background coordination, and message server communication, so a Z report that consumes excessive roll/heap memory (SYSTEM_NO_ROLL) can block shared resources and cause paging at OS level. This explains why the CI appears to ‚Äúhang‚Äù while an app server terminates quickly with a dump.

In your case, the heap parameter distribution is significantly different (especially abap/heap_area_dia, abap/heap_area_nondia, and abap/heaplimit). The CI allows the report to grow longer in heap usage, leading to heavy paging instead of fast termination.

Best practice:

  • Avoid running heavy custom reports on CI

  • Keep memory parameters consistent across instances

  • Ensure Z reports are optimized to fail fast rather than exhaust heap

  • Prefer background/app servers for memory‚Äëintensive programs

That‚Äôs why the same report behaves differently on CI vs. APP servers.

entry.title: Re: how to move existing attachments into new external st...
entry.content: Yes, it is possible, but not directly with RSIRPIRL for SOFFDB. Attachments stored in SOFFCONT1 (SAPoffice / SOFFDB) cannot be moved automatically to a Content Server using RSIRPIRL, as this report mainly supports ArchiveLink/KPro repositories. The recommended approach is: Assign a KPro content repository (OAC0) for new attachments. Use RSBCS_REORG to clean up obsolete SAPoffice documents. For existing attachments, use RSGOS_RELOCATE_ATTA (see SAP Note 2293171) or a custom migration program using KPro APIs. Alternatively, use a certified third‚Äëparty tool (e.g. OpenText, Gimmal, YAC) for mass migration. SAP does not provide a standard report to fully migrate SOFFCONT1 contents to a Content Server.

entry.title: Re: How to migrate from SAP content server to OPENTEXT?
entry.content:
GOS attachments and their relationships to business objects are stored in table SRGBTBREL.
You can identify attachments using fields like TYPEID_A (Business Object), INSTID_A (Object Key), and RELTYPE (e.g. ATTA for attachments, NOTE for notes).
For content storage details, related SAPoffice tables such as SOOD / SOFM / SOC3 or DMS tables like DRAD (if DMS is used) may be required.

entry.title: Re: Assign and Process Purchase requisition
entry.content:
Hi Dinesh,

Yes, your requirement can be effectively achieved by using Purchasing Groups (EKGRP) as the primary organizational driver. The Purchasing Group identifies the buyer or team responsible for the material, and it allows procurement users to filter and process only the PRs assigned to them.

Recommended Approach

  • Assignment: Use transaction ME57 (Assign and Process Purchase Requisitions). Procurement users can filter by their specific Purchasing Group to claim and convert PRs into Purchase Orders.
  • Governance: Implement a Release Strategy to ensure PRs are approved before conversion.
  • S/4HANA Best Practice: If you are on S/4HANA 2022 or later, I highly recommend using Flexible Workflow for Purchase Requisitions. This allows dynamic routing to specific users based on conditions (like Purchasing Group) directly to their Fiori My Inbox.

Configuration Steps (SPRO)

Requirement SPRO Path / Transaction

Purchasing GroupMaterials Management > Purchasing > Create Purchasing Groups (V_024)
Release CharacteristicsMaterials Management > Purchasing > Purchase Requisition > Release Procedure > Procedure with Classification (CT04)
Release ClassesMaterials Management > Purchasing > Purchase Requisition > Release Procedure > Procedure with Classification (CL02)
Flexible WorkflowFiori App: Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions (App ID: F2705)

I hope this helps clarify your process!

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Massive Update Tax Type and Tax Number Type in Busine...
entry.content:
To perform a massive update of Tax Type (Tax Category) and Tax Number once Business Partners have been created, there are two primary recommended approaches for an On-Premise environment.

Option 1: Standard Mass Maintenance (MDC Framework)

If your system has SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) licensed or the "Mass Processing" features active, you should use the modern Consolidation and Mass Maintenance framework. The legacy MASS transaction is not recommended for Business Partners as it does not handle the tax number table (DFKKBPTAXNUM) efficiently.

  • Transaction: MDC_MASS_DATA_CLIENT (or Fiori App: Start Mass Maintenance - Business Partners).
  • Process: Select the Business Partner object (147) and ensure the Tax Numbers entity is included in the scope.
  • Benefit: It provides a UI-driven wizard to upload Excel files, validate data against standard SAP checks, and activate changes in bulk.

Option 2: Custom ABAP Program (BAPI Approach)

If you do not have MDG or prefer a programmatic solution to automate the logic, you can create a simple ABAP report. This follows the Clean Core strategy by using released SAP APIs instead of direct table updates.

Key Function Modules:

Scenario Function Module
Add new Tax dataBAPI_BUPA_TAX_ADD
Modify existing dataBAPI_BUPA_TAX_CHANGE

Code Snippet Logic:

LOOP AT lt_upload_data INTO ls_data.
  CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUPA_TAX_ADD'
    EXPORTING
      businesspartner = ls_data-partner_id
      taxtype         = 'HN1' " Example Tax Type for Honduras
      taxnumber       = ls_data-tax_val
    TABLES
      return          = lt_return.

  IF NOT line_exists( lt_return[ type = 'E' ] ).
    CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT' EXPORTING wait = 'X'.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

Considerations

  • Customizing: Ensure the Tax Category (e.g., 'RS') is maintained in transaction BUPA_TAXNUMTYPE before running your update.
  • Electronic Invoicing: Since these fields are required for e-invoicing, using BAPIs is critical because they trigger the necessary validations that a simple UPDATE statement to table DFKKBPTAXNUM would skip.
  • Documentation: Reference the SAP Help Portal on BP Data Transfer for further technical details.

entry.title: SAP Success Factors Integration with Data Lake
entry.content:
There are various ways to Integrate SAP Success factors with Data Lakes (Azure Data Lake, AWS S3, or SAP HANA Cloud LAKE)

 Possible Approaches

  • Native SAP Solutions
  • SAP Datasphere: This is the primary modern tool for connecting SuccessFactors to a data lake. It uses Replication Flows to extract data via OData and push it into targets like Azure Data Lake Storage (ADLS) Gen2 or the integrated SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake.
  • SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration): Formerly known as CPI, this middleware can be used to build custom integration flows that fetch data from SuccessFactors APIs and send it to various cloud storage endpoints. 
  • Third-Party Middleware (Best for Azure/AWS/Snowflake)

Several no-code/low-code tools offer pre-built connectors to simplify the ETL process: 

  • CData Sync: Automates continuous replication from SuccessFactors to Azure Data Lake. It supports CSV, Parquet, and Avro formats.
  • Rivery: A cloud-native ELT platform that extracts SuccessFactors reports and loads them directly into data lakes or warehouses in a few clicks.
  • Boomi: A common middleware for SAP environments that provides a dedicated SuccessFactors connector for complex data transformations before landing in a data lake. 
  1. SuccessFactors Integration Center
  • SFTP Export: You can use the built-in Integration Center within SuccessFactors to schedule CSV or XML file exports to an SFTP server. Many data lakes (like Azure or AWS) can then be configured to automatically ingest files from that SFTP location.

Implementation Steps

  1. Authentication: Configure OAuth 2.0 or Basic Authentication in SuccessFactors Admin Center to allow the integration tool access to APIs.
  2. Schema Mapping: SuccessFactors data is highly relational. Ensure your target data lake has a defined structure (e.g., Delta Lake or Parquet) to handle the nested employee master data.
  3. Governance & Security: Since HR data is sensitive, ensure the data lake has strict role-based access controls (RBAC) that mirror the permissions set in SuccessFactors. 

 

Conclusion

There are multiple ways to establish integration and sync the data between SAP Success Factors and Data Lakes.

 

Thank You

Regards

Vish

Hi,

The configuration that you are looking at is absolutely correct. But inside the configuration 'Define texts for Purchase orders' we have four folders in the dialogues structure namely

a) Texts for document header

b) Texts for document item

c) Texts for document supplement

d) Headings

As per standard in the folder 'Texts for document header' only F01 is maintained. If you would like additional header texts (ex: shipping instructions texts) to be sent in IDOC's segments E1EDKT1 & E1EDKT2, the associated text IDs (F06-shipping instructions) must be maintained under the folder 'Texts for Document Supplement'

entry.title: Re: Data Lakes Files physical storage and Object Store in...
entry.content:
Hi

In my understanding, when you configure a Space in SAP Datasphere with the Storage Type: SAP HANA Data Lake Files, the data is physically stored in the SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake Files (HDLF) service component underlying your tenant.

This is not a customer-owned external bucket (like your own private AWS S3 or Azure Blob). It is an SAP-managed object store service that is embedded within your Datasphere tenant configuration.

In BDC, when you activate a Data Package in the BDC Cockpit, and data is pushed via APRS to the Foundation Services (FOS) layer,  files are also physically stored in HDLF, even though the technology is the same as the Datasphere, this specific instance is separate and inaccessible to us, while we interact using the BDC Connect API.

In short, you must distinguish between the two entities, even though they share the same underlying technology (HDLF), FOS is SAP-managed, read-only for customers, stores "SAP Data Products" while in Datasphere Object Store , which is managed, read/write, your local table files like parquet or CSV, but this is external to BDC, its like having a separate product, BDC data access is through BDC Connect

entry.title: Re: Assign and Process Purchase requisition
entry.content: Hi Dinesh. Yes, there's a standard SAP process for this. Procurement Manager uses ME5A to review all released PRs across Purchasing Groups/Plants. Then in ME57 (Assign and Process Purchase Requisitions), they assign sources/vendors directly. Buyers see only their assigned PRs in their own ME57 view filtered by Purchasing Group. 100% standard - works in ECC and S/4HANA [SAP Help](https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/af9ef57f504840d2b81be8667206d485/a27fb65334e6b54ce10000000a174cb4.html).

entry.title: Re: Data Lakes Files physical storage and Object Store in...
entry.content:
Hello! Its some way different

In Datasphere (only) you configure a Space in SAP Datasphere with the Storage Type: SAP HANA Data Lake Files, the data is physically stored in the SAP HANA Cloud, Data Lake Files (HDLF) within your tenant. This "Local Table (file)" like parquet or CSV is stored in the HDLF container but its is not a customer-owned external bucket (like your own private AWS S3 or Azure Blob). Instead, it is an SAP-managed object store service that is embedded within your Datasphere tenant configuration, but you can connect to external stores (like S3 or ADLS Gen2) via connections and replication flows.

In BDC, when you activate a Data Package in the BDC Cockpit, and data is pushed via APRS to the Foundation Services (FOS) layer,  files are also physically stored in HDLF , the same as the Datasphere, but this is separate and inaccessible to the customer. We can only access using BDC Connect API

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA‚ÄìDoes Leading Ledger 0L Require the Same Fisca...
entry.content:
Hi @suba2605 ,
In SAP S/4HANA all company codes assigned to the leading ledger (0L) must share the same Fiscal Year Variant (FYV) and Posting Period Variant (PPV). This restriction was introduced to ensure consistency in the Universal Journal (ACDOCA) and enable reliable cross-company reporting. The error in FINSC_LEDGER occurs when company codes with mismatched FYVs or PPVs are assigned to 0L, and the correct resolution is to harmonize these settings across all company codes in the leading ledger.

Let me explain you why the restriction in S/4HANA?

Universal Journal (ACDOCA):
In S/4HANA, all financial postings (FI, CO, AA, ML, etc.) are stored in one table (ACDOCA). To maintain consistent period definitions, the system enforces a single FYV and PPV for all company codes in the leading ledger. Otherwise, cross-company transactions would be misaligned (e.g., one company in period 3 while another is in period 4).

Cross-company reporting:
Consolidated reporting requires aligned fiscal calendars. Different FYVs/PPVs would break group-level reporting and cause inconsistencies in period-based KPIs.

Technical simplification:
ECC allowed flexibility because data was split across multiple tables. S/4HANA‚Äôs design prioritizes harmonization and simplification over flexibility, reducing reconciliation effort.

To resolving the FINSC_LEDGER Error you have to check following assignments.
Use FINSC_LEDGER to review company codes assigned to 0L. Verify their FYV and PPV settings in OBY6 (company code global parameters). Also you have to harmonize settings. Align all company codes under 0L to the same FYV and PPV. If business requirements demand different fiscal calendars, consider Non-leading ledgers: Assign company codes with different FYVs to separate ledgers. Ledger groups: Use ledger groups for reporting flexibility.

Best practice:
Leading ledger (0L) should represent the group standard fiscal year.
Company-specific deviations should be handled via non-leading ledgers or special ledger configurations

Hope my above explanation is helpful for you.

entry.title: Re: SAP ISU FICA clearing document posting
entry.content:
Hi @Mohammed_Yusuf_ficaconsultant ,
What I understand the c0urrent behavior is, When you clear open items (either manually in FP06 or automatically via FPMA), SAP posts one clearing document that includes all debit and credit items matched in that run. If you have multiple payment items (e.g., 2 credits vs. 2 debits), they all get lumped into a single clearing document.
The client requirement is, each payment line item should generate its own clearing document.

To do this follow options are mentioned below.


Option 1. Custom Clearing Logic (BTE / Enhancement)
Use Business Transaction Events (BTEs) or User Exits in FI-CA/FI to control clearing behavior.

Relevant BTEs:
00002040 (Document Clearing)
00002050 (Payment Lot Posting)

You can enhance the clearing routine so that instead of grouping items, it forces SAP to post one clearing document per payment line.

Option 2. Payment Lot Customization
In Payment Lot Customizing (IMG ‚Üí Contract Accounts Receivable ‚Üí Incoming Payments ‚Üí Payment Lot), check if you can adjust the lot posting rules. Sometimes, splitting logic can be controlled by lot item grouping or posting area rules.

Option 3. Batch Job Splitting
Instead of clearing all items in one FPMA run, configure the background job to process each payment lot item separately. This way, each run generates one clearing document.

Option 4. Alternative: Clearing Control via Posting Area 0210
In FI-CA, posting area 0210 (Clearing) controls how clearing documents are generated. You may need to adjust the clearing variant so that it doesn‚Äôt combine multiple items into one document.

Hope one of option can fit to you.

entry.title: SAP SD Plant Rollout ‚Äì Configuration Scope & Common Pitfalls

entry.title: SAPUI5 Table Selection: SingleToggle vs Custom Single-Selection with Checkboxes
entry.content:
Introduction:

While building a table in SAPUI5, I faced the challenge of allowing users to select only one row at a time, while also ensuring a clean and intuitive interface. This led me to explore two approaches for implementing single-row selection using SingleToggle and a custom single-selection with checkboxes approach.

The goal was simple: Allow users to select only one row at a time. However, I also needed to give them a checkbox interface, which led me to try two solutions.

 

Option 1: Using SingleToggle

SAPUI5 offers a built-in SingleToggle selection mode that works well when you don't need checkboxes and only need to highlight one row at a time.

XML View:
<ui:Table
    id="appointmentTable"
    rows="{globalModel>/uiData/Orders/Appointments}"
    selectionMode="SingleToggle"
    rowSelectionChange=".onAppointmentRowSelectionChange"
    enableColumnReordering="false"
    rowHeight="48"
    columnHeaderHeight="56"
    class="sapUiTinyMarginBottom">
</ui:Table>
How it's works?

  • Only one row can be selected.

  • Clicking the same row again deselects it.

  • No checkboxes; just row highlighting.

 SingleToggle is perfect for simple selection without checkboxes.

 

Option 2: Custom Single Selection with Checkboxes

When users expect checkboxes, but you still want to limit selection to one row, you can use MultiToggle mode combined with a custom event handler.

XML View:
<ui:Table
    id="appointmentTable"
    rows="{globalModel>/uiData/Orders/Appointments}"
    selectionMode="MultiToggle"
    rowSelectionChange=".onAppointmentRowSelectionChange"
    enableColumnReordering="false"
    rowHeight="48"
    columnHeaderHeight="56"
    class="sapUiTinyMarginBottom">
</ui:Table>
Controller Logic:
onAppointmentRowSelectionChange: function (oEvent) {
    this.oAppointmentTable = oEvent.getSource();
    const aSelectedIndices = this.oAppointmentTable.getSelectedIndices();

    if (aSelectedIndices.length > 1) {
        const iLastIndex = oEvent.getParameter("rowIndex");
        this.oAppointmentTable.clearSelection();
        this.oAppointmentTable.addSelectionInterval(iLastIndex, iLastIndex);
    }
}
How it's works?

  • Only one checkbox is selected at a time

  • Shows checkboxes for selection

  • Provides intuitive user experience

This custom solution allows for single selection with checkboxes, giving users a familiar UI while ensuring only one row is selected.

 

Choosing the Right Approach

Use CaseRecommended Option

Simple highlight-only single selectionSingleToggle
Need checkboxes but still restrict to a single selectionCustom handler (as shown above)

 

Concluding Thoughts!

SAPUI5 gives us flexibility for row selection. If we just need single selection without checkboxes, SingleToggle is the way to go. However, if checkboxes are required, the custom handler approach ensures users can only select one row at a time while maintaining a clean UX.

Both solutions are simple to implement and offer clear user interactions. This is how I approached the issue, but if you have any other suggestions or methods for handling this, please feel free to share them here. I would love to learn from your experience too!

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! If you found this helpful, please feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

Dear experts, I‚Äôm new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: Re: Not able to find /LRN/S4D400_EXERCISE package
entry.content:
This is a very common issue for learners using the SAP BTP ABAP Trial or a personal system instead of the official SAP Learning System Access (LSA).

The package  LRN/S4D400_EXERCISE (and the table /LRN/S4D400_APT inside it) does not exist on the standard public SAP BTP Trial. It is exclusive to the paid/official training systems provided by SAP Learning System Access.

Since you are likely on the free BTP Trial, you cannot "add" this package. Instead, you must manually create your own objects that mimic the missing ones.

The exercise asks you to copy /LRN/S4D400_APT. This is just a simple Flight table. On the BTP Trial, you have an almost identical table available: /DMO/FLIGHT

entry.title: KPI Tags in SAP Fiori Elements List Report (OData V4) ‚Äî Beyond Analytical Applications
entry.content:
Introduction

KPI (Key Performance Indicator) tags are commonly associated with analytical applications in SAP Fiori, but did you know you can also implement them in standard non-analytical list report pages?

OData V4 in SAP Fiori elements provides a manifest-based configuration approach that lets you add dynamic, clickable KPI indicators to any list report page‚Äîwithout needing an analytical service.

This blog walks you through the official implementation approach to show how to:

  • Configure KPI tags in manifest.json
  • Create reusable KPI fragments with the macros:KPITag building block
  • Bind dynamic data and handle press events
  • Understand the architecture and design patterns

Why KPI Tags Matter in List Reports

A KPI tag is a compact, clickable indicator that displays:

  • A numerical value (e.g., total cost, contribution amount, order count)
  • A unit or measurement (currency, percentage, days)
  • A visual status (color-coded: Success, Warning, Error, Information)
  • Optional icon and tooltip

In list reports, KPI tags provide at-a-glance insights without cluttering the data table. They're especially valuable for:

  • HR & Benefits applications ‚Äî Show headcount, enrollment rates, total costs
  • Sales dashboards ‚Äî Display order counts, revenue, pipeline value
  • Finance reports ‚Äî Highlight outstanding invoices, approvals pending
  • Operations ‚Äî Monitor KPIs like availability, efficiency, cycle time

Part 1: Understanding the Two Approaches

Approach 1: Analytical Applications (Analytical List Pages)

  • Requires an analytical data source with aggregated/pre-calculated data
  • Configured via CDS annotations in the backend as well as manifest configuration in UI
  • Example: SAP Analytical List Pages (ALP)
  • Best for: Large-scale data analysis, multi-dimensional analytics, pre-aggregated metrics

Approach 2: OData V4 List Reports (What This Blog Covers)

  • Uses manifest-based configuration + custom XML fragments
  • Works with any non-analytical OData V4 service
  • Configuration entirely in the frontend (manifest.json + UI5 fragments)
  • Fully customizable via UI5 controller extensions
  • Best for: Standard enterprise list reports, responsive dashboards, interactive KPIs

This approach is ideal for developers who want simplicity and flexibility without backend annotation complexity.

Part 2: Setting Up KPI Tags in manifest.json

KPI tags are registered in the manifest under the keyPerformanceIndicators section within the list report target:

"targets": {
  "mainPage": {
    "type": "Component",
    "id": "Default",
    "name": "sap.fe.templates.ListReport",
    "options": {
      "settings": {
        "contextPath": "/RootEntity",
        "variantManagement": "None",
        "initialLoad": true,
        "keyPerformanceIndicators": {
          "myKPITag": {
            "template": "sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.CustomKPITag"
          },
          "myKPIWithPress": {
            "template": "sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.CustomKPITagWithPress"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Key Points:

  • keyPerformanceIndicators ‚Äî Container for all KPI definitions in this page

  • myKPITag, myKPIWithPress ‚Äî Unique identifiers for each KPI block (you can name these anything)

  • template ‚Äî Path to the fragment file (can be in your app namespace or SAP's example path)

You can define multiple KPI blocks by adding more entries. Each entry corresponds to one fragment template.

Part 3: Building KPI Fragments with the macros:KPITag Building Block

SAP recommends using the KPI building block (macros:KPITag) to maintain consistent design with analytical applications.

Simple KPI Fragment (Static Values)

<core:FragmentDefinition 
  xmlns="sap.m" 
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
  xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros">
  
  <macros:KPITag
    number="0"
    unit="Days"
    status="Error"
    showIcon="true"
    press=".extension.sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customKPIContent.LRExtend.onKPIPressed"
  />
  
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Properties Reference

Property

Type

Purpose

Example

number

Number

The KPI value to display

0, 5000, 15.5

unit

String

Unit or measurement label

"Days", "USD", "%"

status

String

Visual indicator color

"Success", "Warning", "Error", "Information"

showIcon

Boolean

Display status icon

true / false

press

String

Event handler for click

.extension.[controller.path].onKPIPressed

tooltip

String

Hover text

"Total Orders"

visible

Boolean

Conditional visibility

true / false

enabled

Boolean

Enable/disable interaction

true / false

Part 4: Handling KPI Press Events

When a KPI tag is clicked, the press handler in your controller extension is triggered:

Step 1: Define the Controller Extension

In your manifest, register a controller extension for the ListReport:

"sap.ui5": {
  "extends": {
    "extensions": {
      "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
        "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
          "controllerName": "your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

Step 2: Implement the Press Handler

In your ListReportExt.controller.js:

sap.ui.define(
  ["sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension"],
  function(ControllerExtension) {
    return ControllerExtension.extend(
      "your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt",
      {
        onKPIPressed: function(oEvent) {
          const oSource = oEvent.getSource();
          const sKPIId = oSource.getId();
          
          sap.m.MessageToast.show("KPI " + sKPIId + " was pressed!");
          
          // Add custom logic here:
          // - Filter the table
          // - Navigate to detail page
          // - Show breakdown analysis
          // - Trigger backend action
        }
      }
    );
  }
);

Step 3: Register in Fragment

Reference the handler in your fragment's press event:

<macros:KPITag
  number="0"
  unit="Days"
  status="Error"
  press=".extension.your.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt.onKPIPressed"
/>

Part 5: Building Multi-KPI Layouts with FlexBox

For a professional dashboard with multiple KPIs, use FlexBox for responsive layout:

<core:FragmentDefinition 
  xmlns="sap.m" 
  xmlns:core="sap.ui.core" 
  xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros">
  <FlexBox 
    direction="Row"
    wrap="Wrap"
    gap="2rem"
    justifyContent="SpaceAround"
    alignItems="Start">
    
    <!-- KPI 1 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Total Orders" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="1234"
        unit="Orders"
        status="Success"
      />
    </VBox>
    <!-- KPI 2 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Revenue" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="523000"
        unit="USD"
        status="Information"
      />
    </VBox>
    <!-- KPI 3 -->
    <VBox>
      <Label text="Pending Approvals" />
      <macros:KPITag
        number="47"
        unit="Items"
        status="Warning"
      />
    </VBox>
  </FlexBox>
</core:FragmentDefinition>

Part 6: Binding Data Models

To make KPIs dynamic (not just static values), you need to bind them to data models.

Creating a KPI Data Model

In your ListReportExt controller:

onInit: function() {
  const oKPIModel = new sap.ui.model.json.JSONModel({
    totalOrders: 1234,
    revenue: 523000,
    pendingApprovals: 47,
    costStatus: "Success"
  });
  
  this.getView().setModel(oKPIModel, "kpiModel");
}

Binding in Fragment

<macros:KPITag
  number="{kpiModel>/totalOrders}"
  unit="Orders"
  status="{kpiModel>/costStatus}"
/>

Updating Data Dynamically

fetchKPIData: function() {
  const oModel = this.getView().getModel(); // OData model
  
  oModel.read("/RootEntity", {
    success: (oData) => {
      const oKPIModel = this.getView().getModel("kpiModel");
      oKPIModel.setData({
        totalOrders: oData.OrderCount,
        revenue: oData.TotalRevenue,
        pendingApprovals: oData.ApprovalCount
      });
    }
  });
}

Part 7: Best Practices and Design Patterns

1. Responsive Design

  • Use wrap="Wrap" in FlexBox for mobile compatibility
  • Test on different screen sizes
  • Consider hiding KPIs on very small screens if needed

2. Status Color Coding

Use status colors to convey meaning:

  • Success (Green) ‚Äî All good, target met
  • Warning (Orange) ‚Äî Attention needed, approaching limit
  • Error (Red) ‚Äî Critical, action required
  • Information (Blue) ‚Äî Neutral, FYI

3. Meaningful Units

  • Always include a unit if applicable (currency, count, percentage, time)

4. Interactive Press Handlers

Make KPIs actionable:

  • Filter the list to show related records

  • Open a breakdown popover with summary data

5. Loading States

Use busy indicators while fetching data:

<FlexBox busy="{kpiModel>/loading}">
  <macros:KPITag number="{kpiModel>/value}" />
</FlexBox>

Part 8: Troubleshooting Common Issues

Issue

Solution

KPI tags not showing

Verify manifest template path is correct; ensure fragment file exists at that location

Static values work, but binding doesn't

Check model name matches in binding (e.g., {kpiModel>/...}); verify model is set before fragment renders

Press event not firing

Ensure press handler includes .extension. prefix; verify controller extension is registered in manifest

Mobile layout broken

Add wrap="Wrap" to FlexBox; test responsive breakpoints; use sap.ui.Device for responsive logic

Blank KPI in production

Check backend OData service returns required fields; add error handling for failed reads

Part 9: Comparison ‚Äî Analytical List Pages vs. OData V4 Manifest-Based KPIs

Configuration

CDS annotations + Manifest Configuration

Manifest Configuration only

Data Source

Analytical data models with aggregation

Any OData V4 service

Setup Complexity

High (requires analytical CDS views)

Low (JSON config + fragment)

Customization

Framework-driven

Full UI5 flexibility

Performance

Optimized for large aggregations

Good for summary metrics

Event Handling

Predefined navigation & analytics

Custom controller logic

Best For

Enterprise analytics dashboards

Standard business apps with KPI summaries

Learning Curve

Steep (analytics concepts)

Gentle (standard UI5 patterns)

Part 10: Live Example Reference

SAP provides a working example in the Flexible Programming Model Explorer:

Custom KPI Tags in List Report ‚Äî FPM Explorer

This interactive demo shows:

  • Static KPI tags

  • KPI tags with press events

  • Various status types and layouts
  • Responsive behavior

Recommended: Clone this example and adapt it to your use case.

Part 11: What's Next? ‚Äî Custom Charts & KPI Visualization

Coming in Next Blog:

In this blog, we learned how to add interactive KPI tags to any list report page. But what happens when users click on a KPI?

In the next blog, we'll explore:

  1. Building Custom Charts ‚Äî Visualize KPI data using chart libraries
  2. Mapping KPI Data to Chart Models ‚Äî Prepare and transform data from your OData service
  3. Opening Charts in Dialogs/Popovers ‚Äî Display detailed analysis when KPI is clicked
  4. Multi-dimensional Visualizations ‚Äî Show data breakdowns by different dimensions
  5. Dynamic Chart Updates ‚Äî Refresh visualizations based on filter selections

Imagine clicking on a "Revenue" KPI and instantly seeing a pie chart breakdown by product category, or a bar chart comparing revenue across regions. That's what we'll build next!

Resources

  • SAP Fiori Elements Documentation ‚Äî Creating Key Performance Indicators
  • macros:KPITag API Reference
  • FPM Explorer ‚Äî Custom KPI Tags Example
  • SAP Community ‚Äî Fiori Elements
  • Analytical List Page Documentation

Summary

KPI tags are not limited to analytical applications. By leveraging OData V4's manifest-based configuration and SAP UI5's flexible architecture, you can add powerful, clickable KPI indicators to any list report page.

Key Takeaways:

  • KPI tags work with standard (non-analytical) OData V4 services

  • Configuration is simple: manifest entry + fragment + optional controller logic

  • Full customization via UI5 ‚Äî binding, styling, event handling

  • Responsive design built-in via FlexBox

  • Press handlers enable analysis and interaction

Whether you're building HR dashboards, sales pipelines, financial reports, or operational monitors, KPI tags can elevate user experience by providing instant insights at a glance.

Start experimenting with the FPM Explorer example today, and stay tuned for our next blog on custom charts and KPI visualization!

Questions or feedback? Drop a comment below‚ÄîI'd love to hear about your KPI use cases!

entry.title: Re: SAP BP best practice: payer vs bill to when member VA...
entry.content:
Hey,

 

 

1. Core Principle (Most Important)

In SAP SD/FI, VAT liability and invoice legality must follow the VAT-liable legal entity, not the entity that pays.

Whoever‚Äôs VAT number must appear on the invoice should normally be the payer for tax determination purposes.

The paying agent is economically settling the invoice, but is not VAT-liable.

This drives almost all configuration decisions.

2. Recommended BP Role Model (High Level)

- Member = Payer (VAT-liable party)

- Paying Agent = Bill-to / Alternative Payer

Not the other way around.

Why:

  • VAT determination in SD is driven by payer at sales-org level (as you stated)

  • Invoice must legally belong to the member

  • Credit notes must legally be raised to the member

  • VAT reporting must reference the member

The paying agent is acting on behalf of the member, not replacing them as VAT debtor.

3. BP Role Assignment (Concrete)

Member (VAT-liable)

BP Role Purpose
Sold-to (SP)Contractual member
Payer (PY)VAT determination & legal invoice party
Bill-to (optional)If invoice header needs member name
FI CustomerReceives invoice & credit memo

Key settings

  • Member‚Äôs VAT registration number maintained in:

    • BP ‚Üí Tax Numbers

    • Assigned to correct country & tax category

  • This VAT number will:

    • Drive VAT determination

    • Print on invoice

    • Appear on credit notes

Paying Agent

BP Role Purpose
Bill-to (BP)Invoice recipient (C/O)
Alternative PayerCash settlement
FI CustomerPayment handling

Key settings

  • Paying agent does NOT drive VAT

  • VAT number can exist for information, but:

    • Must NOT be used for tax determination

  • Address can be printed as C/O line

4. Invoice Layout (C/O Requirement)

This is a form issue, not a master-data misuse issue.

Correct approach

  • Invoice header:

    • Legal party: Member

    • VAT number: Member

  • Address block:

    • ‚ÄúC/O Paying Agent‚Äù

  • SAP forms (Adobe / SmartForms):

    • Use Bill-to address

    • Prefix with ‚ÄúC/O‚Äù

    • Reference Sold-to / Payer for VAT & legal text

This avoids distorting the BP model just to satisfy formatting.

5. VAT Number Maintenance (Critical)

Best Practice

Entity VAT Number Usage
MemberMandatoryTax determination + invoice
Paying AgentOptionalInformational only

Do NOT

  • Put paying agent VAT number on payer role

  • Override tax country to force tax logic

If VAT is driven by payer + sales org, the payer must be the member.

6. Credit Notes & Payment to Another BP

This is standard SAP functionality.

Credit Note Issued To Member

  • Credit memo posted to:

    • Member AR account

  • VAT reversed correctly (member VAT number)

Payment Made to Paying Agent

Use Alternative Payee functionality.

Option A ‚Äì Alternative Payee (Recommended)

In BP ‚Üí FI Customer ‚Üí Payment Transactions:

  • Assign Alternative Payee = Paying Agent

  • Enable:

    • ‚ÄúAlternative payee allowed‚Äù

  • Result:

    • Credit memo stays on member AR

    • Payment is made to paying agent‚Äôs bank

This is fully standard SAP FI.

Option B ‚Äì One-Time or Clearing Account (Not Recommended)

Sometimes used, but:

  • Breaks audit trail

  • Complicates AR reconciliation

  • Avoid unless regulatory reasons

7. Bank Master Data (Best Practice)

Paying Agent

  • Maintain bank account(s) here

  • Used for:

    • Incoming payments

    • Outgoing credit note payments

Member

  • No bank account required if they never receive cash directly

Payment flow

Credit Memo ‚Üí Member AR Payment Run ‚Üí Paying Agent bank account

Linked via Alternative Payee.

8. Standard SAP Patterns You Can Reference

SAP Concepts Used

  • Business Partner roles (SP / BP / PY)

  • VAT determination via payer

  • Alternative Payee (FI-AR)

  • C/O addressing via invoice form

  • Credit memo posting to original payer

SAP Notes / Keywords to Search

(Exact note numbers vary by release)

  • ‚ÄúAlternative Payee in Accounts Receivable‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúVAT determination payer sales organization‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúSD invoice C/O address‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúAgent payer scenario SAP SD FI‚Äù

9. Summary Recommendation

Topic Recommendation
PayerMember
VAT numberMember only for tax
Paying agent roleBill-to + Alternative Payee
Invoice layoutMember legal entity, Paying Agent as C/O
Credit notesPosted to Member
PaymentTo Paying Agent bank via Alternative Payee
CustomizationMinimal ‚Äì mostly standard

 

 

Best,

Edrilan Berisha

entry.title: RANDOM FOREST ITERATION 1
entry.content:
DATA COLLECTION AND PREPARATION

  1. First, we collected approximately 12 years of available daily stock data, for a total of 3,091 observations:
  2. Then we created additional measurements ‚Äúgauges‚Äù such as RSI and MACD.
    • Relative Strength Index (RSI from 0 to 100) measures strength and speed for stock price changes.  Interpretation: RSI above 70 is commonly interpreted as overbought and historically associated with increased risk of pullbacks (leading to lower stock price).
    • Moving Average Convergence / Divergence (MACD) captures changes in momentum by comparing short- and long-term exponential moving averages.
  3. Next step included running a few raw data plots to visually check the data.  Of course, we first split the stock prices data set 80/20 into training (blue line) and testing (red line). The numbers are in Vietnamese dong. ($1 USD ~ 26,300 VND).  Obviously, the data is split chronologically, so that 80% training set is the oldest data and 20% validation is the newest.

RStudio is the statistical platform to perform these analyses and random forest predictions.

Daily returns (stock price on day 2 / stock price on day 1) are not quite normally distributed so we take a note of this for subsequent improvements (iteration 2):

 

TREE SELECTION AND PRUNING

Although the random forest model used in this analysis is globally nonlinear, at any given day the next-day price can be viewed as a function of several state variables‚Äîrecent prices, momentum, volatility, and volume‚Äîcorresponding to a point on a high-dimensional response surface. Over a sufficiently small neighborhood around the current market state, this surface can be locally approximated by a linear function. In this sense, even a complex nonlinear model behaves approximately linearly in the immediate vicinity of the observations on which it is trained.

This local approximation helps explain why short-horizon predictability may exist despite the absence of reliable long-term forecasting power. Small changes in inputs lead to proportionally small changes in the predicted price, allowing the model to exploit local structure without committing to a global trend. As the market state evolves and moves away from this neighborhood, however, the approximation deteriorates quickly, naturally limiting the persistence of predictability and helping to explain why even modest transaction costs can overwhelm the signal.

Formally, the next-day price can be represented as a multivariable function

where the inputs ‚Äã represent features such as lagged prices, average trend, volatility.

Algorithmic Perspective: RMSE Minimization and Ensemble Averaging

From an algorithmic standpoint, this behavior arises not from explicit linearization, but from the way random forests are constructed.  Each decision tree is built through a greedy, recursive procedure that selects split points to locally minimize the root of the mean squared error (RMSE) of the next-day price prediction.  At each node, the algorithm chooses the variable and threshold that most reduces in-sample error, without considering the global structure of the tree or future splits.  This process produces a piecewise-constant approximation that is locally optimized for short-horizon accuracy.  The random forest then averages predictions across many such trees, each trained on a bootstrap sample and a random subset of predictors, which reduces variance and stabilizes forecasts.  As a result, the model captures local regularities in the data while remaining inherently sensitive to changes in market conditions, reinforcing the short-lived nature of the observed predictability.

Formally, at each node of a given tree, the algorithm selects a split (j, s) ‚Äî variable x and threshold s ‚Äî that minimizes the in-sample squared error within that node.  Let I denote the set of observations reaching the node.  The optimal split solves

where IL and IR are the left and right child nodes induced by the split.  Y bars are the mean next-day prices within each child.  This greedy optimization is repeated recursively until stopping criteria ‚Äî such as minimum node size or maximum depth ‚Äî are reached.

Because each tree is trained on a bootstrap sample of the data, approximately one-third of observations are excluded from the construction of any given tree.  These unused observations provide a natural out-of-sample testing set for that tree, forming the basis of the out-of-bag (OOB) error used to assess predictive performance.

Next came the testing of the OOB and tree pruning.

Without full statistical rigor of rules such as 1-SE, just visually it appears that 100 trees is enough to bring the error (Mean Square Error) down to almost its minimum. We can formally compare various error levels by the number of trees to make the pruning decision:

  Trees Train_RMSE Test_RMSE

1     5    1182.18   2397.00

2    20    1080.01   2244.43

3    50    1067.00   2222.47

4   100    1036.87   2207.22

5   200    1058.35   2183.04

One can see that the rate of MSE decrease drops, or slows down, between 100 and 200 trees. Based on this information, our heuristic cutoff is established at 100 trees.

PREDICTION: RMSE

 

The predicted distribution tells the following story:

  • Extreme ends move further away from the ideal line (red dotted line).
  • Vertical dotted lines between the predicted values (stock prices) and the red dotted line, if squared and summed, comprise the MSE.
  • Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) is 2188 (in Vietnamese dongs) which translates into less than 3% of the stock price level.  

So, we can proceed to plotting the predictions against the historical data.

The blue line represents historical stock prices (80% oldest), the red line is also historical stock prices, but newest (our model‚Äôs testing data) and green dots are the stock price predictions. First plot shows the entire data and second one zooms in on the testing data mostly:

Visually, the green dots (predictions) track the red line (actual stock prices) closely. There are some notable deviations though, but in general for the two-year period our basic random forest model performs reasonably well.

 

BASIC RANDOM FOREST REFINEMENT

Given the noticeable deviations of predictions from the actual stock prices, we introduce more predictors:

  1. Lag_1: one day prior share price. While this limits the predictive interval to only one day, this addition, as we see later, improves the predictive power.
  2. SMA_5 which is simple 5-day moving average =  

 

 

  1. EMA_12 which is 12-day exponential moving average, i.e. moving average where we assign higher weight to the most recent stock price

where a=2 / (N+1)

 

  1. We construct an average intraday price proxy for smoothing purposes as follows:  avg_daily=(open+low+high)/3. 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The model essentially asks, ‚ÄúGiven the prior day‚Äôs stock price and the short-term trend & momentum today, what price do we expect tomorrow?‚Äù

  • Lag-1 ‚Üí inertia / memory
  • SMA & EMA ‚Üí short-term trend
  • RSI ‚Üí overbought / oversold pressure
  • MACD ‚Üí momentum turning points

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Addition of these incremental variables brings the RMSE significantly down: from 2188 (below 3% of the stock price) to 809 which is below 1% of the stock price.

In plain English: this random forest regression predicts stock prices fairly closely to their actual levels at short horizons. 

 

RANDOM FOREST: TRUE PREDICTIONS

The logic of the random forest model has been clear: train the model on the 80% of historical data then make predictions for the 20% of the newest historical data, i.e., test the model on the unseen data. From this point, we went further ‚Äì predicting Masan Group‚Äôs stock prices for a few days in a row.  Specifically

  • Original model‚Äôs last day of known stock price was Friday December 12, 2025. How does the model perform on the following Monday when the markets open?  I.e., what stock price does it predict for Monday December 15, 2025?
  • For Tuesday December 16, 2025, stock prediction, I add the prices from Monday and re-run the model to predict December 16 price. I repeated this process for two weeks through December 26 especially noting the period of ‚ÄúSanta rally‚Äù as during this period the deviations may be interesting.

Rather than holding the model fixed, we re-train the random forest each day as new observations become available. This expanding-window approach allows the model to adapt to evolving market conditions and prevents mechanical error accumulation.  This differs from recursive multi-step forecasting with a fixed model, where forecast errors compound over time.

Here are the results:

While each daily forecast is strictly out-of-sample, the resulting multi-day prediction path should be interpreted as a conditional scenario generated by a sequence of re-trained models rather than as a set of independent forecasts from a fixed model.  Predictions generated this way paint an interesting picture:

  • Typical prediction error or edge: ~0.5%‚Äì1.5%
  • Often much smaller day-to-day moves
  • Pragmatically, any usable signal is small relative to the price level, consistent with liquid asset classes
  • This may be important if the round-trip costs run up to 0.10% (5 bps for entry and exit trades respectively)

Here is the plot of these predictions against the actual stock price movements from December 12, 2025:

We can interpret a few representative trading days and our predictions:

 

 

 

December 15, 2025

December 25, 2025

December 26, 2025

Indecision / Balance day

Pause within an uptrend?

Sellers‚Äô close

Price moved higher intraday, but did not hold near the highs

Both buying and selling pressure were present

Neither side achieved a decisive close

Predicted price sits above the candle body, near the upper range

The model leaned toward upside continuation

Actual outcome was a balanced session rather than follow-through

 

 

Price was pushed higher intraday

Sellers closed the session lower than the open

The selling move was limited in magnitude

Predicted price lies below the candle body

The model anticipated downward pressure

Direction aligns with the close, though magnitude was overstated

 

Session closed below the open (seller close)

Price traded significantly lower intraday

The close occurred well above the session low

Indicates rejection of lower prices, but not a bullish close

Predicted price lay above the actual close

The model captured the presence of demand away from the lows

It did not capture the seller-controlled close

 

 

RANDOM FOREST ON MASAN GROUP STOCK PRICE: CONCLUSION

At first glance, the random forest model appears to perform well: predicted prices track actual prices closely, and RMSE falls below 1% once lagged price and moving-average features are introduced. However, a closer examination reveals that much of this apparent predictive power is mechanical rather than informational.

Equity prices are highly autocorrelated at short horizons, particularly for relatively low-volatility stocks such as Masan Group.  

  • As a result, introducing the prior day‚Äôs price (Lag_1) almost mechanically improves prediction accuracy, effectively reducing the problem to ‚Äútomorrow equals today plus noise.‚Äù
  • In this sense, the model‚Äôs success is not evidence of alpha generation, but rather a reflection of short-term price persistence.

Although each daily forecast is strictly out-of-sample, the resulting multi-day path should still be interpreted cautiously: economically rather than statistically.  Because predictions are generated by a sequence of re-trained models rather than a single fixed model, the path represents a conditional evolution under expanding information rather than a fully independent set of forecasts.

INTO THE FUTURE: ITERATION 2: RETURN-BASED RANDOM FOREST (vs. Baselines)

These observations do not weaken the analysis; instead, they clarify the path toward a more rigorous modeling framework.  A more economically meaningful approach is to model price changes rather than price levels, for example by predicting log returns.

This transformation removes non-stationarity, forces the model to learn directional information, and reduces reliance on trivial persistence effects.

In the subsequent iteration, we will also introduce the trading costs, e.g., at 5bps.  This estimate highlights that even modest transaction costs can exceed the typical day-to-day predictive edge, rendering statistically accurate forecasts economically unprofitable.

In addition, any refined model must be evaluated against simple baseline alternatives such as a random walk (e.g., ‚Äútomorrow = today‚Äù), ARIMA, or moving-average extrapolation.  

  • Only if the random forest consistently outperforms these ‚Äúlazy‚Äù benchmarks can it be said to add genuine predictive value.
  • Beating the baseline is, in practice, the definition of alpha.

In this sense, the current model serves an important diagnostic role: it demonstrates both the power and the limitations of machine learning applied naively to equity prices, and it motivates a more disciplined next iteration grounded in financial time-series principles.

entry.title: Re: Master Data Governance new UIBB Data Controller
entry.content:
Hi,

 

Please refer this link fo rmore insights

 

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/f5d3e1005efd4e86acf9a65abf428082/9202f3ee6ddc41118b325207b432a287.html?version=2023.000&q=OXK3

Collapse or Expand UIBBs

With this feature, you can choose to collapse or expand UIBBs. By using the Collapse button, you are limiting the number of UIBBs processed in a UI roundtrip, which improves performance.

Assignment of Data Controller

With this feature, all authorization checks that might impact the maintenance of business partners having data controllers are considered. You can maintain the Data Controller not Required (BUT000-DC_NOT_REQ) attribute for organizations with the new attribute, DC_NOT_RQ for entity type BP_CENTRL. Table BUT_DC_LINK is reflected in the BP data model as entity type DC_LINK with new UIBB Data Controllers. The list of data controllers is visible in the single object maintenance UIs. It remains read-only and cannot be used for manual data maintenance. The implicit assignment of data controllers is executed as part of the activation of CR.

Comments for Address (ADRCT) and Communication Data (ADRT)

You can add and maintain comments for addresses in the Comments field in the Addresses UIBB. The ADRCT table is reflected in the BP data model in entity types AD_POSTAL/ADT_POSTL and shown in the new column Comments in the UIBB Addresses. The language-dependent comments can be shown in the UIBB Comments by choosing the Detail button.

Comments for international versions of addresses are shown in the UIBB International Versions by choosing the Detail button.

The ADRT table is reflected in the BP data model in multiple entity types and shown in the new column Comments in relevant communication UIBBs. The language-dependent comments can be shown in the UIBB Comments by choosing the Comment button.

Shareholder Relationships (BUT053)

With this feature, you can maintain shareholder relationships and their corresponding company interest attributes. The BUT053 table is reflected in the BP data model as entity type BP_SHREL/TD_BPSH with the new UIBB Shareholder Relationships.

 

thanks & regards,

Balakrishna vegi

entry.title: Re: No billing documents were generated. Please see log....
entry.content:
Hi! It looks like the Exception 7 in function module VIEW_KUAG2 is the real issue here . This usually happens because the system can't find the Sales Area data for internal customer 0000030004 in the supplying company's records.

Expand the error log

Could you please click the "+" sign next to the error in your screenshot? Expanding that tree will reveal the specific sub-messages, which usually point directly to the missing field or segment that is blocking the billing document.

Recommended checks

  • Master Data: Use transaction BP to verify that customer 0000030004 is fully extended to the Sales Organization and Distribution Channel of the supplying company .
  • STO Configuration: Confirm that this specific internal customer is correctly assigned to the supplying plant within your intercompany purchasing settings .
  • Partner Functions: Ensure that the Sold-to and Payer functions are correctly maintained for the relevant sales area.

Helpful SAP Notes

  • SAP Note 207021: Covers errors related to reading customer master data.
  • SAP Note 301254: Specifically addresses the "No billing documents were generated" error.
  • SAP Note 80233: A comprehensive guide for troubleshooting Intercompany STO and billing setups .

entry.title: Re: Bapi for tcode : /SAPPCE/DPCK01
entry.content:
There is no standard BAPI (Business Object Repository) specifically named for transaction /SAPPCE/DPCK01. To automate this transaction's logic for Credit-Side Down Payment Chains, you must use internal function modules within the /SAPPCE/ namespace.

Key Function Modules

  • /SAPPCE/DPC_MASTER_MAINTAIN: Used for creating or updating the master data of the Down Payment Chain (DPC).
  • /SAPPCE/DPC_POSTING_CREATE: Used for generating transactional postings like partial invoices or final payments within the chain.
  • /SAPPCE/DPC_DPCHAIN_STATUS: Retrieves current balances and retention amounts for a specific chain.

Technical Reference Table

Object Type Technical Name Purpose

Header Table/SAPPCE/TDPC01Stores DPC numbers, company codes, and vendor data.
Items Table/SAPPCE/TDPC19Contains individual transaction records for each chain.
BAdI/SAPPCE/DPC_POSTINGUsed for custom logic during the posting process.

entry.title: Re: Is there any Standard Purchase Requisition uploader i...
entry.content:
In Cloud Public Edition, there is no generic "mass upload" Fiori app for standard Purchase Requisitions. However, you can achieve this through specific scenarios or APIs.

Standard Upload Methods

The availability of a standard uploader depends on your specific license and functional scope:

  • Central Procurement: The app Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally allows for mass creation and updates using an Excel-based "Offline Mode". Check Purchase Requisition Item | SAP Help Portal
  • Migration Cockpit: For bulk creation during implementation or data cleanup, the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit provides a dedicated migration object for Purchase Requisitions. Check 3350690 - Create Purchase Requisition and Purchase Order via template | SAP Knowledge Base Article

Recommended APIs for Customization

To develop a custom Excel uploader while adhering to Clean Core principles, use the following released APIs:

API Technical NameName Description
API_PURCHASEREQUISITION_2OData V4Recommended for side-by-side extensions (BTP) or external integrations.
I_PurchaseRequisitionTPABAP RAPReleased Business Object for Developer Extensibility (on-stack) using ABAP RAP.
PurchaseRequest_InSOAPSuitable for asynchronous, message-based integrations from third-party systems.

For a modern approach, you can utilize SAP Build Process Automation to read an Excel file and trigger the OData V4 API without writing extensive custom code.

entry.title: Re: Pricing procedure in Purchase Contracts
entry.content:
As per standard behaviour, in Purchase Contracts, the unit price of the material is determined primarily by the gross price condition (PB00/PBXX or custom ZB00). Supplementary conditions (discounts, surcharges, freight, etc.) maintained in the calculation schema (RM0002 or custom ZM0002) do not change the base unit price of the material. Instead, they are applied as additional values during price determination in follow-on documents (RFQs, Purchase Orders, etc.). This means, it is expected system behavior that supplementary conditions do not directly alter the contract‚Äôs item-level unit price. They are considered only when the contract is referenced in a PO or RFQ.

Why Supplementary Conditions don‚Äôt impact Unit Price is because of the following:

Contract pricing logic:
Contracts store the agreed gross price per material. Supplementary conditions are stored but not rolled into the displayed ‚Äúunit price.‚Äù

Calculation schema design:
The schema RM0002 (or your ZM0002) applies supplementary conditions in pricing simulations, but the contract document itself shows only the gross/base condition as the unit price.

System consistency:
SAP keeps the contract unit price stable to avoid confusion, while supplementary conditions flow into transactional documents where actual net price is calculated.

So in short, if your business requirement is to see them reflected in the contract‚Äôs unit price, you must customize the pricing procedure or write a routine to include them.

entry.title: Re: Bill of services from Projects-CJ20N.
entry.content:
Instead of treating trucks as externally procured services, you can model them as internal resources within Project System and integrate with Controlling.

How it works:

Define Activity Types in CO
Create activity types for truck usage (e.g., ‚ÄúTruck Hours‚Äù). Assign cost centers representing the fleet or vehicle groups. Maintain planned/actual rates (cost per hour).

Use Internal Activities in PS Network/Project
Assign internal activities to the project network or WBS elements. Capture actual hours worked by each truck against the project. Hours can be entered manually or via CATS (Cross‚ÄëApplication Time Sheet).

Settlement & Billing
Actual truck hours posted as activity allocations flow into PS. Resource‚Äërelated billing can then pick up these internal activity postings and generate customer invoices. This way, billing is based on internal service consumption rather than external procurement.

Advantages of this approach are

  • Directly maps truck usage as internal effort rather than external services.
  • Granular tracking by vehicle number if you set up cost centers or statistical orders per truck.
  • Weekly/monthly reporting possible via PS/CO reports (hours, costs, utilization).
  • Billing flexibility: You can bill based on hours, rates, or aggregated values.

entry.title: BehaviorInvocationException: Too few values in second queue in function useOneAsMany
entry.content:
Problem Statement

In SAP CPI Message Mapping, I faced a OneAsMany violation due to mismatched occurrences between two source fields:

  • Company Code ‚Üí Occurrence = 1

  • PRODUCTTAXITEM ‚Üí Occurrence = 2
    So basically, due to difference in context change, I was not able to use it in value mapping where the target field occurrence is also 2 times, due to this if i use it without OneasMany, it is throwing error : target field require value for it.

This resulted in the following OneAsMany rules being violated:

Rule 1: Input 1 should not contain repeating values in the same context.

Business requirement was to:

  • Increase the context of Company Code

  • Match it with the number of PRODUCTTAXITEM occurrences

  • Repeat only the first Company Code value for all PRODUCTTAXITEM contexts.

    Groovy code used is as follows:

    import com.sap.it.api.mapping.*

    // Function name must match the name used in Message Mapping UI
    def void replicateCompanyCode(
    String[] companyCode,
    String[] productTaxItem,
    Output companyCodeOut,
    MappingContext context) {

    // Guard checks
    if (companyCode == null || companyCode.length == 0 ||
    productTaxItem == null || productTaxItem.length == 0) {
    companyCodeOut.addSuppress()
    return
    }

    // Take only the first Company Code
    String firstCompanyCode = companyCode[0]

    // Create context based on PRODUCTTAXITEM count
    for (int i = 0; i < productTaxItem.length; i++) {
    companyCodeOut.addValue(firstCompanyCode)
    companyCodeOut.addContextChange()
    }
    }

    Unit test :

entry.title: A context change is NOT always caused by addContextChange() alone.
entry.content:
A context change is NOT always caused by addContextChange() alone.
CPI also creates context changes automatically when parallel queues advance differently.

What is really happening in your case

You have THREE relevant queues aligned in mapping:

  1. productTaxItem

  2. some other node (likely RECORDTYPE / TaxCode / something parallel)

  3. companyCodeOut (your UDF output)

Your UDF only controls companyCodeOut,
but CPI aligns all queues together.

Notice:

  • companyCodeOut value is SAME (BB01)

  • But another queue changes context (B2 ‚Üí 22)

CPI inserts an implicit context change to stay aligned with the other node.

So:

  • Context 2 ‚Üí created by your UDF

  • Context 3 ‚Üí created automatically by CPI due to parallel node context shift

That‚Äôs why they appear together.

entry.title: How to Create a ServiceNow Incident via REST API Using ABAP (OAuth 2.0)
entry.content:
Prerequisites

  • ServiceNow instance access with API credentials (Client ID, Client Secret)
  • SAP NetWeaver with HTTP Client (CL_HTTP_CLIENT) and JSON support (/UI2/CL_JSON)

Step 1: Obtain OAuth2 Token from ServiceNow

First, you need to POST your client credentials to ServiceNow‚Äôs /oauth_token endpoint to get a bearer token. This token authorizes subsequent API calls.

ABAP Code:

FORM get_servicenow_token USING iv_token_url TYPE string
                              iv_client_id TYPE string
                              iv_client_secret TYPE string
                         CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
                                  cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, the access_token can now be used as a Bearer token.

Step 2: Build the JSON Payload

Create a JSON structure that describes the incident.

ABAP Code:

lv_json_body =
'{' &&
'"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
'"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
'"category":"Data",' &&
'"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
'"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"impact":"2",' &&
'"urgency":"2"' &&
'}'.

Step 3: Create the Incident via POST API

Now, make a POST request to the ServiceNow incident table, including your access token for authorization.

ABAP Code:

FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, cv_result will contain the incident response from ServiceNow.

Step 4: Combine the Steps in Your Report

Your main program calls these subroutines in sequence.

Example Main Logic:

* Get the access token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token
               USING lv_token_url
                     lv_client_id
                     lv_client_secret
               CHANGING ls_token
                     lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Create the incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident
                    USING lv_post_url
                          ls_token-access_token
                          lv_json_body
                   CHANGING lv_result
                            lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.

Final Notes

  • Security: Never hardcode sensitive data in productive programs‚Äîuse secure storage.
  • Error Handling: Always add robust error handling and log failures for troubleshooting.
  • Data Mapping: Adjust JSON fields based on ServiceNow table and your organization‚Äôs requirements.

Conclusion

Integrating SAP and ServiceNow allows you to automatically manage ITSM incidents directly from SAP ABAP.  The above example demonstrates OAuth token retrieval and incident creation using ABAP.  Adapt and build on this foundation to suit your business requirements.

Happy Integrating! Let me know in the comments if you have any questions or need clarification on any step.

 

Complete ABAP CODE:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZSNOW
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Utility: ServiceNow Incident API Integration
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*

REPORT zsnow.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_token,
         access_token TYPE string,
         scope        TYPE string,
         token_type   TYPE string,
         expires_in   TYPE i,
       END OF ty_token.

DATA: lv_token_url     TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/oauth_token',
      lv_client_id     TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-id...',
      lv_client_secret TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-secret...',
      lv_post_url      TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/api/now/table/incident',
      lv_json_body     TYPE string,
      ls_token         TYPE ty_token,
      lv_err           TYPE string,
      lv_result        TYPE string.

* Prepare JSON Body

lv_json_body = '{' &&
               '"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
               '"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
               '"category":"Data",' &&
               '"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
               '"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"impact":"2",' &&
               '"urgency":"2"' &&
               '}'.

* Step 1: Get the Token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token USING lv_token_url
                                   lv_client_id
                                   lv_client_secret
                          CHANGING ls_token
                                   lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Step 2: Create Incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident USING lv_post_url
                                         ls_token-access_token
                                         lv_json_body
                                CHANGING lv_result
                                         lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.



*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Get OAuth Token from ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM get_servicenow_token
  USING    iv_token_url TYPE string
           iv_client_id TYPE string
           iv_client_secret TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " get_servicenow_token

*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Create an Incident in ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " create_servicenow_incident

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GB Material Master Consumption Question in SAP P...
entry.content: Hello @Ashley_Hung Thanks for your question. The numbers in the Consumption tab are only updated when you post goods issues with movement types that are configured to update ‚Äúconsumption‚Äù and when the material has a Forecast view with a period indicator. If your transactions are receipts or issues with movement types that don‚Äôt update consumption, or if the Forecast view was created after the postings, the tab will stay at zero. Common reasons why you see zeros: 1.The postings are not ‚Äúconsumption‚Äù postings.Purchase receipts (101), stock transfers (301/311), customer deliveries (601) and many other movement types do not update material master consumption in standard.Typical movement types that DO update consumption in standard are withdrawals such as 201/202 (to cost center), 261/262 (to production order), 281/282 (to project/WBS), 551/552 (scrapping), etc. 2.Forecast view was added after the transactions.MVER is only updated from the moment the Forecast view and period indicator exist. Past postings are not retroactively written to consumption. 3.You are looking at the wrong plant or period.Consumption is plant-specific and period-based. If reversals were posted in the same period, net consumption can be zero. 4.Movement type configuration does not update consumption.If your process uses a custom movement type or a variant whose ‚ÄúUpdate Consumption in Material Master‚Äù flag is off, consumption will not be updated. Be aware: there is no standard job in S/4HANA Cloud to backfill historical consumption into the material master. If you need history for forecasting, use analytics based on material documents rather than relying on the Consumption tab. Hope it can help. Best Regards Dave

entry.title: Re: Disable download statement button in compensation wor...
entry.content:
HI, Isn`t it the option related to the Enable Bulk Print in Executive Review.

Enable Bulk Print in Executive Review: When this setting is ticked, users can view the Bulk Print Statement icon on the Salary, Stock, and Bonus tabs on the Executive Review page, based on the includeStatementLink attribute set in the XML template. Users can then download Compensation, Variable Pay and Combined statements in PDF format for the filtered employees.
